conclusion: The problem involves determining the angle between the velocity and the horizontal direction when the slider lands at point C.
The slider is compressed and released, converting potential energy in the spring into kinetic energy at point B.
The height difference between the platform and the circular arc is h = 0.53 m, the radius of the arc is R = 0.4 m, and the angle θ = 37°.
The vertical distance from the top of the arc to the ground is calculated as h - R(1 - cos θ) = 0.53 - 0.4 × (1 - 0.8) = 0.45 m.
The horizontal distance between points B and C is x_BC = 0.9 m.
Using the vertical motion equation y = h - 0.5 g t^2, the time of flight is calculated as t = sqrt(2 × 0.45 / 9.8) ≈ 0.3 s.
Using the horizontal motion equation x = v_x t, the horizontal velocity at point B is determined as v_B cos 37° = 3 m/s, leading to v_B = 3.75 m/s.
The vertical component of the velocity at point C is calculated as v_yC = v_B sin 37° - g t = 2.25 - 2.94 = -0.69 m/s.
The horizontal component of the velocity at point C is v_xC = v_B cos 37° = 3 m/s.
The angle φ between the velocity and the horizontal direction is calculated as tan φ = v_yC / v_xC = -0.69 / 3 = -0.23, leading to φ ≈ -13.0°.
The angle between the velocity and the horizontal direction when the slider lands at point C is 13.0° below the horizontal.
